metadata.title: Highly dispersed Pd catalysts prepared by a sonochemical method for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide

Scheme 1 Reaction pathways and Gibbs free energies in the direct synthesis of H2O2. Scheme 1 Fig. 1 STEM images of catalysts. (a): Pd/TiO2(S), (b): Pd/TiO2(I), (c): Pd/SiO2(S), and (d): Pd/SiO2(I). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 XRD graphs of catalysts. (a): Pd/SiO2(S), Pd/SiO2(I) and SiO2; (b): Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and TiO2; (c): magnified graphs of Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and TiO2 (2θ=35–43); and (d): magnified graphs of Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and TiO2 (2θ=43–50). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XPS spectra of catalysts. Pd peaks of Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I), Pd/SiO2(S) and Pd/SiO2(I). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XPS data of catalysts. Oxygen peak of (a): Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and TiO2 and (b): Pd/SiO2(S), Pd/SiO2(I) and SiO2. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 H2O2 direct synthesis experimental results. (a): H2 conversion, H2O2 yield, H2O2 selectivity of each catalyst. (b): H2O2 production rate of each catalyst. Test conditions: 293K, 1atm, 1.7mg Pd, 150mL ethanol/water (4/1vol. ratio) mixture containing 0.15mM KBr and 0.03M H3PO4, Stirring rate 1200rpm, H2 gas flow=2mL/min, and O2 gas flow=20mL/min. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Catalyst recycle test results (H2O2 production rate of Pd/TiO2(S)). Recycle tests were performed under the same conditions as the H2O2 direct synthesis tests. After each reaction, Pd/TiO2(S) was collected by filtering and dried at 383K for 12hours. Then, the Pd/TiO2(S) was reduced in H2 gas, which was followed by a reaction test. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2O2 decomposition experimental results. Test conditions: Decomposition tests under (H2 +N2) were performed using the same conditions as the direct synthesis tests except that the O2 gas flow was replaced with N2 gas. Decompositions tests under (pure N2) were performed using the same conditions as the hydrogenation tests, except that the H2 gas flow was replaced with N2 gas. Fig. 7 Table 1 Pd loading, surface area and dispersion data. Table 1 Catalysts Pd loading (wt.%) a Pd surface area (m2/gPd) b Pd dispersion (%) b Pd/TiO2(S) 0.84 73.8 16.6 Pd/TiO2(I) 0.75 32.6 7.3 Pd/SiO2(S) 0.84 21.4 4.8 Pd/SiO2(I) 0.70 28.5 6.4 a The loading amount of Pd is measured by ICP-OES analysis. b The Pd surface area and Pd dispersion of each catalyst are calculated by CO pulse chemisorption. Highly dispersed Pd catalysts prepared by a sonochemical method for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide Geun-Ho Han a 1 Myung-gi Seo a 1 Young-Hoon Cho a Sang Soo Han b Kwan-Young Lee a c ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea b Center of Computational Science, Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST), 14 Hwarang-ro, Seoul 02792, Republic of Korea Center of Computational Science Korea Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) 14 Hwarang-ro Seoul 02792 Republic of Korea c Green School, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul 02841, Republic of Korea Green School Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author at: Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145 Anam-ro, Seoul, 02841, Republic of Korea. Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University 145 Anam-ro Seoul 02841 Republic of Korea 1 These authors contributed equally to the manuscript Graphical abstract Pd catalysts prepared by a sonochemical method that is known to be effective in metal dispersion are applied to direct H2O2 synthesis. To determine the effect of the preparation method on the catalytic performance, Pd catalysts were supported on TiO2 and SiO2 by a sonochemical method and general incipient wetness method (IWI), and supports were compared. The sonochemical preparation method achieved the highest Pd dispersion value of 16.6% in the TiO2 supported catalyst, which is attributed to a synergistic effect between the sonochemical method and TiO2 support. A near-homogeneous and small size nucleation is often reported in sonochemical methods, and oxygen vacancies in TiO2 are reported to be strong adsorption sites for Pd nucleation. However, SiO2 support has not been reported to have obvious oxygen vacancies, and sonochemically prepared Pd/SiO2 showed the lowest Pd dispersion in addition to a large Pd particle size. In the direct synthesis of H2O2, a remarkably high H2 conversion of 22% was achieved in sonochemical Pd/TiO2, which led to the highest H2O2 yield of 16% and H2O2 production rate of 729.0mmol/gPd h. Keywords Palladium catalyst High dispersion Sonochemical preparation Titanium dioxide Direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide 1 Introduction Hydrogen peroxide is a valuable and eco-friendly oxidant compared to other oxidants (e.g., HNO3, N2O, and NaClO) [1–3]. A major advantage of hydrogen peroxide is that the byproducts of hydrogen peroxide (O2 and H2O) following oxidation are ‘greener’ than those of other oxidants (e.g., NOx, N2O and NaCl) [4,5]. Also hydrogen peroxide is the most efficient oxidant; the content of active oxygen in hydrogen peroxide is 47% by weight, which is the highest value among oxidants, with the exception of molecular oxygen [5,6]. The global demand of hydrogen peroxide has increased due to its widespread use as a bleaching agent of pulp or paper and as a raw material for various syntheses that produce chemicals in the presence of proper catalysts (e.g., titanium silicalite-1) [7,8]. Hydrogen peroxide can be used in conjunction with a titanium silicalite-1 catalyst for ammoximation, hydroxylation, oxidation and epoxidation processes [8–12]. As the demand for hydrogen peroxide has increased, the number of plants that manufacture hydrogen peroxide has also increased [5]. Most hydrogen peroxide is produced by an anthraquinone oxidation process (AO process), but it has several drawbacks in environmental and economic aspects [5,13]. The AO process uses highly toxic chemicals, including anthraquinones (e.g., 5,6,7,8-tetrahydroanthrahydroquinone and anthrahydroquinone) and organic solvents (e.g., naphthalene and octanol), and is economically viable only at a large scale plant due to its complicated setup [13]. The transportation of hydrogen peroxide from manufacturing sites to the point of use requires an additional cost and is accompanied by the danger of explosion [13]. Therefore, alternative hydrogen peroxide production processes that use greener materials with an on-site route have been studied. The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide from H2 and O2 has received attention as a potential candidate [14–16]. The direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide uses greener solvents (e.g., water, ethanol and methanol), and the byproducts of the process, H2O and O2, are eco-friendly. In addition, it can be economically operated at a much smaller scale than the AO process; therefore, on-site installation is feasible and the cost of hydrogen peroxide transportation is obviated. Also, on-spite produced hydrogen peroxide can be directly fed into other processes, such as hydrogen peroxide to propylene oxide (HPPO) [4,5,17]. The reaction pathways in the direct synthesis of H2O2 are presented in Scheme 1 . H2O2 is directly synthesized from the reaction of H2 and O2 (path 1). However, all of the reactions that occur in direct synthesis of H2O2 have negative Gibbs free energies, leading to spontaneous side reactions [4]. The undesired side reactions of water formation (path 2), H2O2 dissociative hydrogenation (path 3) and H2O2 direct decomposition (path 4) can decrease the selectivity of H2O2; therefore, these side reactions must be inhibited to increase the H2O2 selectivity and yield [4]. Approaches to increasing the yield of hydrogen peroxide have been studied in various aspects of reaction media components, and the selection of the proper solvent, acids and halide ions additives has been studied to increase the reactivity of the direct synthesis of H2O2 [4,18–25]. Solvents (e.g., ethanol and methanol) are used to increase the solubility of the gas reactants (H2 and O2), leading to a higher conversion of reactants [24,25]. In recent studies, the role of acid additives in direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide is not fully understood, but it has been experimentally noted that acids suppress hydrogen peroxide decomposition on supported Pd0 catalysts [18]. The role of halide ion additives (e.g., F−, Br−, Cl− and I− ions) has also been studied [4,19–23,26]. In particular, Br− and Cl− ions can decrease H2O formation and H2O2 decomposition by selectively blocking the energetic corner and edge sites of Pd that are known to prefer undesired side reactions [19–23]. I− ions strongly adsorb on the Pd metal surface, resulting in low H2 conversion. F− ions also promote H2 conversion as well as indiscriminately promote side reactions such that the net effects of F− ions are trivial [4]. With these additives or solvents, the production rate, yield, and selectivity of hydrogen peroxide in direct synthesis can be improved [4,20,27]. Precious metals (e.g., Pd, Pt and Au), the main active sites, are widely used for various catalytic reactions [26,28–36]. In particular, Pd metal has effective catalytic activity in the direct synthesis of H2O2 among active metals [26,29–32]. To utilize limited precious metals, methods for modifying a metal to maximize its activity have been investigated. Recently, various strategies, including morphology control of Pd [37,38], Pd-based alloys (e.g., Pd-Au and Pd-Pt) [39–42], investigation of predominant active sites of Pd [39,43] and enhancement of a Pd dispersion that can increase active sites [44,45], have been performed to enhance their reactivity. Manipulation of the interactions between metals and supports are also effective at enhancing metal dispersion, which mainly affects the Pd surface area, including doping atoms into supports (e.g., N doping in TiO2), using reducible supports (e.g., TiO2 and CeO2) and modifying the structure of supports [46–49]. In addition, appropriate preparation methods, including the sonochemical method, deposition-precipitation and incipient wetness impregnation (IWI), can also enhance metal dispersion [45,50,51]. The sonochemical method specifically includes a sonication process (20–40kHz) that leads to an acoustic cavitation [17,52–54]. The cavitation phenomenon accompanies the formation, growth and collapse of bubbles in media and the collapse of bubbles within a nanosecond, leading to an extremely fast temperature cooling rate (>1011 K/s) around bubbles [17,52,55]. This fast cooling rate inhibits the organization and growth of particles, which results in homogenous and small nucleation [52,54–56]. P. Weerachawanasak et al. used the sonochemical method to disperse Pd metal on a TiO2 support in comparison with the general incipient wetness impregnation method and found that the sonochemically supported Pd/TiO2 catalyst had a higher Pd dispersion than the IWI method. [45]. In this study, we prepared Pd/TiO2 and Pd/SiO2 catalysts by the sonochemical method and IWI [4,57,58]. The SiO2 support has been widely used in direct synthesis of H2O2, and it was hence selected for comparison with TiO2. The catalytic properties of each catalyst were analyzed by XRD, XPS, N2 adsorption-desorption, and STEM, and the catalytic properties were correlated to the activities of H2O2 direct synthesis from H2 and O2 by applying the catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals Palladium nitrate hydrate (Pd(NO3)2·xH2O, Sigma-Aldrich), titanium dioxide (TiO2, P25, Degussa), silicon dioxide (SiO2, ≥99%, pore size 60Å, Sigma-Aldrich), deionized water (18.2MΩ), acetone (C3H6O, ≥99.5%, DaeJung) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2, 35wt.% in H2O, Sigma-Aldrich) were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of the catalysts 2.2.1 Sonochemical approach Palladium nitrate hydrate (0.0217g, Sigma-Aldrich) and 1g of support (TiO2 or SiO2) were dissolved in 25mL of DI water with gentle mixing over 12hours. The suspension was then sonicated for 6hours at 40kHz and 303K before it was collected and washed by centrifugation. The catalysts were dried at 383K for 12hours and calcined at 773K for 6hours. The catalysts were reduced using a H2/N2 gas mixture (1:9vol. ratio) at 623K. These prepared catalysts are denoted as Pd/TiO2(S) or Pd/SiO2(S) based on the support. 2.2.2 Incipient wetness impregnation (IWI) Palladium nitrate hydrate (0.0217g, Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in DI water (support’s pore volume) to make precursor solution. After metal impregnation by dropping the precursor solution on 1g of support (TiO2 or SiO2) according to the general incipient wetness method, the catalysts were dried at 383K for 12hours and calcined at 773K for 6hours. The catalysts were reduced using a H2/N2 gas mixture (1:9vol. ratio) at 623K. These prepared catalysts are denoted as Pd/TiO2(I) or Pd/SiO2(I) based on the support. 2.3 Characterization of the catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms were obtained using a BELSORP-max (BEL Japan Inc., Japan). The specific surface area and total pore volume of the catalysts were calculated using the BET equation and plotted isotherms. Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was used to measure the mass fraction of Pd in each catalyst. A JY Ultima2C (Jobin Yvon, France) dual ICP-OES spectrometer was used. Before measurement, the samples were dissolved in aqua regia and hydrofluoric acid (total 5mL), which was followed by analysis on a 473K hot plate at a reduced pressure. The CO pulse chemisorption method was used to calculate the exposed surface area of Pd and dispersion of Pd on each catalyst. An Autochem II (Micromeritics, US) instrument was used at 313K with an inject loop gas of CO/He (CO:He=1:9). The underlying assumption in this calculation is that one molecule of CO adsorbs onto each exposed palladium atom. From the level of CO adsorption, we can calculate the number of surface Pd atoms. A Tecnai G2 F30 instrument (FEI Company, USA), operated at 300kV, was used to obtain scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images of each catalyst. All samples were dispersed in ethanol and dropped on a 300mesh Cu grid, and the loaded grids were dried at room temperature under ambient conditions. The analyses were performed at the Korean Basic Science Institute (KBSI) in Seoul. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to determine the crystal structures of the catalysts. The measurements were taken with a D/MAX-2500/PC (Rigaku, Japan) at a scanning speed of 2°/min (2θ=10°–90°) with Cu-Kα irradiation (α=1.5406Å). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were used to measure the electronic properties of O and Pd in each catalyst. XPS was performed using an ESCA2000 (VG microtech, U.K.), and measurements were performed under 10−10 torr with an AlKa X-ray anode source. 2.4 Reaction test: direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 The direct synthesis of H2O2 was performed with each catalyst in a double-jacket glass reactor with stirring (1200rpm). The reaction medium (150mL) consisted of ethanol and water (ethanol:water, volume ratio=1:4) with 0.15mM KBr and 0.03M H3PO4. The amount of Pd metal in the catalyst was fixed at 1.7mg, and the volumetric flow rate of the reactant gas stream was 22mL/min (H2:O2, volume ratio=1:10). The reaction was performed at 293K and 1atm for 3hours. After reaction, the concentration of H2O2 was calculated using iodometric titration [59]. The H2 concentration was determined via gas chromatography (Younglin, ACME6000 using a Carbosieve SΙΙ (60–80mesh))-packed column and a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity, H2O2 yield and H2O2 production rate were calculated using Eqs. (1), (2), (3) and (4), respectively. (1) H 2 O 2 c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = m o l e s o f H 2 r e a c t e d m o l e s o f H 2 supplied × 100 (2) H 2 O 2 s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = m o l e s o f H 2 O 2 f o r m e d m o l e s o f H 2 r e a c t e d × 100 (3) H 2 O 2 y i e l d ( % ) = m o l e s o f H 2 O 2 f o r m e d m o l e s o f H 2 supplied × 100 (4) H 2 O 2 p r o d u c t i o n r a t e ( m m o l / g P d · h ) = m m o l e s o f H 2 O 2 f o r m e d w e i g h t o f P d ( g ) i n c a t a l y s t × r e a c t i o n t i m e ( h ) × 100 2.5 Catalyst recycle tests Catalyst recycling tests were examined with Pd/TiO2(S). Recycle tests were performed under the same conditions as the H2O2 direct synthesis tests. After each reaction, Pd/TiO2(S) was collected by filtering and it was dried at 383K for 12hours. Then, Pd/TiO2(S) was reduced in H2 gas, which was followed by the reaction test. 2.6 Decomposition tests of hydrogen peroxide Decomposition tests of hydrogen peroxide were examined under a (H2 +N2 mixture) flow and (pureN2) flow. The decomposition test under (H2 +N2) was examined using the same conditions as the reaction tests (Section 2.4), except that O2 gas was replaced with N2 gas. The decomposition test under (pureN2) was also examined using the same conditions as the decomposition test under (H2 +N2) (Section 2.6), except that only N2 gas was used. In both decomposition tests, 1mL of H2O2 (35wt.% in H2O) was injected into the reaction media (150mL DI water with 0.15mM KBr and 0.03M H3PO4) at the beginning of the hydrogenation test. The H2O2 concentration was estimated twice, immediately after H2O2 injection and after the reaction finished (3hours). The H2O2 conversion in the hydrogenation tests was calculated by the iodometric titration method using Eq. (5): (5) Hydrogen peroxide conversion ( % ) = Initial concentration of H 2 O 2 − final concentration of H 2 O 2 Initial concentration of H 2 O 2 × 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of TiO2 and SiO2 were measured, and their specific surface area and total pore volume were calculated using the BET equation. The TiO2 support exhibited a specific surface area of 50.0m2/g and total pore volume of 0.29mL/g. The SiO2 support showed much larger values of 575.1m2/g and 0.92mL/g, respectively. The amount of Pd loaded in the different catalysts is listed in Table 1 . The difference between Pd loading is insignificant (0.7–0.84wt.%). All of the reaction tests were performed with a constant amount of Pd (1.7mg) using ICP-OES data (Pd loading in Table 1). Additionally, these values were used to calculate the Pd surface area and Pd dispersion in CO-chemisorption analyses as well as the H2O2 production rate in reaction tests. As mentioned, the Pd surface area (m2/gPd) is directly correlated with the number of active sites. As expected, Pd was highly dispersed in a sonochemically synthesized Pd/TiO2(S) catalyst, which led to the highest Pd surface area and Pd dispersion among all catalysts (73.8m2/gPd and 16.6%, respectively). However, Pd/SiO2(S) showed the lowest Pd surface area and dispersion (21.4m2/gPd and 4.8%, respectively). This clear distinction was only shown in sonochemically synthesized catalysts, and by contrast, IWI catalysts presented relatively similar properties. The reason for this definite difference between Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/SiO2(S) may be related to the synergistic effect between the sonochemical method and TiO2 support. An oxygen vacancy is a type of defect in the TiO2 support; there have been many studies on the role of oxygen vacancies in metal nucleation sites [60–63]. Sanz et al. concluded that metal nucleation occurs in oxygen vacancies and that Pd adsorption at these vacancies is stronger than adsorption at lattice oxygen according to DFT calculations [63]. Therefore, we suggest that the TiO2 support is favourable to form Pd nucleations in its oxygen vacancies. By comparing Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I), we can establish the effect of the sonochemical method on the small size nucleation of TiO2. Although both catalysts use TiO2 with oxygen vacancies as support material, the Pd surface area of Pd/TiO2(S) (73.8m2/gPd) is more than two-fold higher than that of Pd/TiO2(I) (32.6m2/gPd). The sonochemical method promoted smaller nucleation of Pd nanoparticles compared to the IWI method. As a result, we concluded that the sonochemical method using Pd and TiO2 results in a high dispersion of Pd via a synergistic effect. Specifically, the high Pd dispersion is due to the oxygen vacancies, which are well known for being nucleation sites with strong Pd adsorption [64] and the small size of nucleation of Pd, which has been previously reported for sonochemical methods [60]. STEM images of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 and support the CO-chemisorption data as well as the beneficial effect of the sonochemical method; the images are correlated to the CO-chemisorption data. In Fig. 1, the Pd/TiO2(S) catalyst showed the smallest Pd particles, which was due to the small size nucleation of Pd in the oxygen vacancies. Pd/TiO2(I) and Pd/SiO2(I) showed similar Pd particle sizes, and Pd/SiO2(S) exhibited a large Pd particle size. Interactions between metal and support can also affect the catalytic properties and metal dispersion [45,65]. As for the TiO2 support, a reducible oxide, it has been reported that electron exchange occurs between metal and TiO2 in the H2 reduction process [65]. The following XRD and XPS analyses were performed to investigate their properties after reduction. Fig. 2 shows the X-Ray diffraction (XRD) diffractogram of each catalyst. Fig. 2(a) shows the XRD peaks of Pd/SiO2(S), Pd/SiO2(I) and the SiO2 support alone. Low intensity palladium metal peaks are observed in Pd/SiO2(S) and Pd/SiO2(I), and this low intensity may be ascribed to a low amount of Pd loading [65]. Fig. 2(b) presents peaks of Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and the TiO2 support alone. As expected, there are two phases, anatase and rutile (ratio of anatase/rutile=86/14) [61]. The palladium metal peaks in the Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I) catalysts are not clearly distinguished (JCPDS #87-0645). To determine the difference between TiO2 supported catalysts, Fig. 2(c) and (d) shows the overlapped graphs of Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I) and TiO2 (2θ=35–43 and 2θ=43–50, respectively). The XRD peaks of Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I) are slightly shifted to a higher degree than the TiO2 support throughout the theta domain. These results may imply that the TiO2 support and Pd metal affect each other, altering their properties. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed to investigate the electronic state of the catalysts, specifically Pd metal and oxygen. It has been reported that an electron exchange occurs between metal and TiO2 through the reduction process [45,65], as can be observed via XPS analyses (Fig. 3 and 4 ). The XPS spectra presented in Fig. 3 shows the Pd 3d3/2 and Pd 3d5/2 peaks of each catalyst (Pd/TiO2(S), Pd/TiO2(I), Pd/SiO2(S), and Pd/SiO2(I)), which can be assigned to Pd0 and Pd2+, respectively. The Pd XPS peaks of Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I) are characterized by a lower binding energy than those of Pd/SiO2(S) and Pd/SiO2(I). This result indicates that the Pd metal of the Pd/TiO2 catalysts is more electron-rich than that of the Pd/SiO2 catalysts [65]. The electron enrichment of Pd on the TiO2 support is due to the exchange of electrons between Pd and TiO2 [65,66], which could be explained by DFT calculation studies. F. Jinli Zhang et al. investigated the Pd electronic states on perfect and defective TiO2 by DFT calculations, and they suggested that Pd metal in oxygen vacancies exchanged more electrons than that in lattice oxygen [60,62]. Specifically, the difference between preparation methods was investigated by comparing the Pd peak of Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I). The overall peaks seem similar due to a sufficient reduction process (sufficient electron exchange), however the Pd2+ peak shoulder of Pd/TiO2(I) was observed more clearly than that of Pd/TiO2(S). This was because the Pd in Pd/TiO2(S) was more highly dispersed than that in Pd/TiO2(I), which increased the contact area between Pd and TiO2 in Pd/TiO2(S). As a result, Pd in the Pd/TiO2(S) exchanged a greater amount of electrons in the reduction process, which led to a less clear Pd2+ peak in Pd/TiO2(S) (the Pd 0/Pd2+ ratios in Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I) are 2.9 and 2.2, respectively). Fig. 4(a) displays the oxygen peak information of the TiO2 and Pd/TiO2 catalysts, which is presented to strengthen the explanation of electron exchange shown in Fig. 3. As mentioned above, the electron exchange between Pd and TiO2 made the TiO2 support electron-deficient and Pd electron-rich. It is found that the oxygen peak of Pd/TiO2 catalysts is slightly shifted to a higher binding energy (Fig. 4(a)), which represents an electron-deficient state. On the other hand, no difference was observed in the oxygen peak of the SiO2 support and Pd/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 4(b)) because the support SiO2 showed no obvious electron exchange with metal in previous studies. These XPS spectra demonstrate that there was an obvious electron exchange between Pd and the TiO2 support. 3.2 Reaction test results: direct synthesis of H2O2 H2 from O2 Fig. 5 (a) presents the H2 conversion, H2O2 selectivity and H2O2 yield of the catalysts. The H2 conversion is mainly affected by the Pd surface area. Thus, the H2 conversion is partially proportional to the Pd surface area of each catalyst (H2 conversion of Pd/TiO2(S): 22%>Pd/SiO2(S): 14%>Pd/SiO2(I): 12%>Pd/TiO2(I): 11%); notably, Pd/TiO2(S) gives the highest H2 conversion (22%) due to its remarkably high Pd surface area (73.8m2/gPd). However, although the Pd surface area of Pd/TiO2(I) (32.6m2/gPd) was similar to the that of Pd/SiO2(I) (28.5m2/gPd), Pd/TiO2(I) presented a slightly lower H2 conversion than the Pd/SiO2(I) catalyst. J. D. Bracey demonstrated that the SMSI (strong metal-support interaction) state, which is caused by electron exchange, can decrease the ability to absorb H2 [67]. Therefore, the electron-exchanged SMSI state was responsible for the low H2 conversion of Pd/TiO2(I). Despite this drawback, Pd/TiO2(S) still exhibited the highest H2 conversion owing to its much larger Pd surface area. As a result, Pd/TiO2(S) also presented the highest H2O2 yield (16%) and H2O2 production rate (729.0mmol/gPd h) (Fig. 5(b)). H2O2 selectivity is also presented in Fig. 5(a). Overall, Pd/TiO2 catalysts exhibited lower H2O2 selectivity than Pd/SiO2 catalysts, and Pd/TiO2(S) presented the lowest H2O2 selectivity. The factors that affect H2O2 selectivity, as suggested by previous studies, are the Pd particle size and electronic conditions [68,69]. A smaller Pd particle size results in a higher ratio of energetic sites to less energetic sites. These energetic sites are favorable to H2O formation; therefore, smaller sized Pd particles lead to lower H2O2 selectivity [68]. And electron-rich Pd surfaces result in lower H2O2 selectivity than electron-deficient Pd surfaces [69]. This electronic property was demonstrated in the XPS data, with a shift to a lower binding energy (Fig. 3). As a result, these drawbacks made Pd/TiO2(S) have the lowest selectivity. 3.3 Catalyst recycle test results To test the stability and reusability of the catalyst, recycle tests were performed on the most active species (Pd/TiO2(S)). Pd/TiO2(S) was consecutively recycled and reused three times, and the corresponding H2O2 production rates are shown in Fig. 6 . There was no observable decrease in the rate between runs, which indicates that there was no catalytic deactivation in recycle tests below three trials. 3.4 H2O2 decomposition test results H2O2 decomposition is a key side reaction that contributes to reduction in the overall production rate of H2O2. As shown in Scheme 1, decomposition of the product can occur via several reaction pathways: ‘H2O2 dissociative hydrogenation’ (path 3) and ‘direct decomposition’ (path 4). Decomposition tests were performed under (H2 +N2) or (pure N2) flows. Under (H2 +N2 mixture) gas flow, both paths 3 and 4 are followed and under (pure N2) gas flow, only path 4 is followed. As shown in Fig. 7 , the extent of product decomposition under (H2 +N2) and (pure N2) flows differed significantly (in the range of 25%–39% and 1%∼4%, respectively), and Pd/TiO2(S) and Pd/TiO2(I) presented with higher H2O2 decomposition (%) than Pd/SiO2(S) and Pd/SiO2(I). Notably Pd/TiO2(S) had the highest decomposition (39%) compared to the other catalysts (25%–27%). This result can be correlated to the Pd surface area and is in agreement with the observation that at the largest Pd surface area of Pd/TiO2(S), all side reactions (paths 2–4) would also indiscriminately occur [4]. As a result, the largest Pd surface area of Pd/TiO2(S) also resulted in higher H2O2 decomposition. Although Pd/TiO2(I) and Pd/SiO2(I) exhibited similar Pd surface areas (32.6m2/gPd and 28.5m2/gPd, respectively), Pd/TiO2(I) showed greater H2O2 decomposition under (H2 +N2) (27.0%) and under (pure N2) (2.9%) than Pd/SiO2(I) (24.8% and 1.6%, respectively). In fact, H2O2 decomposition under (pure N2) in Pd/TiO2(I) is approximately two-fold higher than that of Pd/SiO2(I). This result is attributed to the differences between TiO2 and SiO2. Anh et al. reported that H2O2 decomposition is caused by oxygen vacancies because these vacancies react with H2O2, leading to H2O formation [70]. In spite of these disadvantages (i.e., low H2O2 selectivity and high H2O2 decomposition), the synergistic effect between the sonochemical method and oxygen vacancies in TiO2 gave Pd/TiO2(S) the highest conversion of H2 (22%). This high conversion overcame the low H2O2 selectivity of Pd/TiO2(S) and resulted in the highest yield (16%) and production rate (729.0mmol/gPd h) of H2O2 among all of the tested catalysts 4 Conclusions Pd/TiO2(S) prepared by the sonochemical method exhibited an improvement in the conversion of H2 because of a synergistic effect between the sonochemistry and TiO2 support. This synergistic effect resulted in a high Pd surface area (73.8%) owing to small particle nucleation at oxygen vacancies. CO-chemisorption analyses and STEM images confirmed this nucleation pattern as well as the benefits of the sonochemical method, including small Pd particles in Pd/TiO2(S). However, there were several disadvantages to the Pd/TiO2 catalysts as well. Electron exchange between Pd and TiO2, which led to an electron-rich state of Pd (XPS) in the Pd/TiO2 catalysts, caused a reduction in H2O2 selectivity. In addition, the ratio of energetic to less energetic sites increased with a small Pd particle in Pd/TiO2(S). As a result, Pd/TiO2(S) presented with lower H2O2 selectivity. Despite the decrease in product selectivity, Pd/TiO2(S) exhibited remarkably high H2 conversion (22%) because of the large Pd surface area, resulting in the highest H2O2 yield (16%) and H2O2 production rate (729.0mmol/gPd h) among all of the tested catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Pd catalysts prepared by a sonochemical method that is known to be effective in metal dispersion are applied to direct H2O2 synthesis. To determine the effect of the preparation method on the catalytic performance, Pd catalysts were supported on TiO2 and SiO2 by a sonochemical method and general incipient wetness method (IWI), and supports were compared. The sonochemical preparation method achieved the highest Pd dispersion value of 16.6% in the TiO2 supported catalyst, which is attributed to a synergistic effect between the sonochemical method and TiO2 support. A near-homogeneous and small size nucleation is often reported in sonochemical methods, and oxygen vacancies in TiO2 are reported to be strong adsorption sites for Pd nucleation. However, SiO2 support has not been reported to have obvious oxygen vacancies, and sonochemically prepared Pd/SiO2 showed the lowest Pd dispersion in addition to a large Pd particle size. In the direct synthesis of H2O2, a remarkably high H2 conversion of 22% was achieved in sonochemical Pd/TiO2, which led to the highest H2O2 yield of 16% and H2O2 production rate of 729.0mmol/gPd h.
coredata.dc:title: Highly dispersed Pd catalysts prepared by a sonochemical method for the direct synthesis of hydrogen peroxide
